## Sous-module 7.1.5 : Advanced Chaos Engineering (35h)

### 7.1.5.1 : Chaos Engineering Principles
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Chaos engineering definition | Discipline of experimenting on systems to build confidence in capability to withstand turbulent conditions |
| b | Why chaos engineering | Find weaknesses before they cause outages |
| c | Chaos vs testing | Testing: known conditions, Chaos: unknown unknowns |
| d | Scientific method | Hypothesis → experiment → analysis |
| e | Steady state hypothesis | Define normal behavior |
| f | Minimize blast radius | Control experiment scope |
| g | Run in production | Real conditions matter |
| h | Automate experiments | Continuous chaos |
| i | Principles from Netflix | Chaos Engineering (book) |

### 7.1.5.2 : Chaos Experiment Design
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Experiment structure | Hypothesis, method, metrics, abort conditions |
| b | Steady state metrics | What to measure as "normal" |
| c | Fault injection types | Infrastructure, application, network |
| d | Magnitude | Start small, increase gradually |
| e | Duration | Short experiments first |
| f | Scope | Single service → multiple services |
| g | Blast radius control | Limit impact of experiments |
| h | Abort conditions | When to stop experiment |
| i | Rollback plan | How to restore normal state |

### 7.1.5.3 : Infrastructure Chaos
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Instance termination | Kill random instances |
| b | Availability zone failure | Simulate AZ outage |
| c | Region failure | Simulate region outage |
| d | Disk failure | I/O errors, full disks |
| e | Memory pressure | Consume memory |
| f | CPU stress | Consume CPU |
| g | Clock skew | Time synchronization issues |
| h | DNS failure | DNS resolution failures |
| i | Certificate expiration | TLS certificate issues |

### 7.1.5.4 : Network Chaos
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Latency injection | Add artificial delay |
| b | Packet loss | Drop percentage of packets |
| c | Bandwidth limitation | Throttle network speed |
| d | Network partition | Split network |
| e | DNS manipulation | Wrong DNS responses |
| f | TCP issues | Connection resets, timeouts |
| g | TLS failures | Certificate errors |
| h | Service dependency failure | Upstream/downstream failures |

### 7.1.5.5 : Application Chaos
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Exception injection | Force application errors |
| b | Resource exhaustion | Connection pools, file handles |
| c | Memory leaks | Gradual memory consumption |
| d | Thread starvation | Exhaust thread pools |
| e | Database chaos | Slow queries, connection failures |
| f | Cache chaos | Cache failures, inconsistency |
| g | Queue chaos | Message delays, drops |
| h | Third-party failures | External API failures |

### 7.1.5.6 : Chaos Tools
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Chaos Monkey | Netflix instance termination |
| b | Gremlin | Commercial chaos platform |
| c | LitmusChaos | Kubernetes-native chaos |
| d | Chaos Mesh | CNCF chaos tool |
| e | Toxiproxy | Network chaos proxy |
| f | Chaos Toolkit | Open source framework |
| g | AWS Fault Injection Simulator | AWS native chaos |
| h | PowerfulSeal | Kubernetes chaos |
| i | Pumba | Docker chaos |
| j | Chaos Blade | Alibaba chaos tool |

### 7.1.5.7 : GameDays
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | GameDay definition | Planned chaos exercise with team |
| b | GameDay objectives | Test incident response, find weaknesses |
| c | Planning | Scenarios, participants, schedule |
| d | Roles | Facilitator, observers, participants |
| e | Scenario design | Realistic failure scenarios |
| f | Execution | Run scenarios, observe response |
| g | Debriefing | Discuss findings, action items |
| h | Documentation | Record learnings |
| i | Frequency | Quarterly or more often |
| j | Escalation | When to stop GameDay |

### 7.1.5.8 : Chaos in CI/CD
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Continuous chaos | Automated chaos experiments |
| b | Chaos as tests | Chaos experiments in pipelines |
| c | Pre-production chaos | Staging environment experiments |
| d | Canary chaos | Chaos on canary deployments |
| e | Progressive rollout chaos | Increasing chaos with rollout |
| f | Automated validation | Verify steady state after chaos |
| g | Chaos observability | Monitor chaos experiments |
| h | Chaos reports | Automated experiment reports |

## PROJET 7.1 : SRE Platform (64h)

### Architecture du Projet
```
SRE Platform
├── SLO Management
│   ├── SLI data collection
│   ├── SLO calculation engine
│   ├── Error budget tracking
│   ├── SLO dashboard
│   └── Budget alerts
│
├── Incident Management
│   ├── Incident creation API
│   ├── Severity classification
│   ├── Incident timeline
│   ├── Status page integration
│   └── Postmortem generator
│
├── Capacity Planning
│   ├── Metrics collection
│   ├── Trend analysis
│   ├── Forecast generation
│   ├── Capacity dashboard
│   └── Alerts for capacity issues
│
├── Chaos Engineering
│   ├── Experiment definition
│   ├── Fault injection
│   ├── Steady state monitoring
│   ├── Experiment reports
│   └── Automated experiments
│
├── Toil Tracking
│   ├── Toil logging
│   ├── Toil categorization
│   ├── Automation suggestions
│   ├── Toil reports
│   └── ROI calculations
│
└── Production Readiness
    ├── PRR checklist
    ├── Automated checks
    ├── Review workflow
    ├── Approval tracking
    └── Service catalog
```

### Livrables Détaillés

| # | Livrable | Heures | Description |
|---|----------|--------|-------------|
| 1 | SLO engine | 8h | Calculate SLIs and SLOs from metrics |
| 2 | Error budget tracker | 6h | Track budget consumption over time |
| 3 | SLO dashboard | 6h | Visualize SLO status and trends |
| 4 | Incident management API | 8h | Create, update, track incidents |
| 5 | Status page | 4h | Public incident communication |
| 6 | Postmortem template generator | 4h | Generate postmortem from incident |
| 7 | Capacity forecaster | 8h | Predict future capacity needs |
| 8 | Chaos experiment runner | 8h | Execute and monitor chaos experiments |
| 9 | Toil tracker | 4h | Log and categorize toil |
| 10 | PRR automation | 4h | Automated production readiness checks |
| 11 | Integration tests | 2h | End-to-end testing |
| 12 | Documentation | 2h | User guide and API docs |

### Technologies
- Backend: Go ou Python
- Database: PostgreSQL (SLO data), TimescaleDB (metrics)
- Queue: Redis (real-time updates)
- Frontend: React (dashboards)
- Chaos: Custom + LitmusChaos integration
- Metrics: Prometheus integration
- CI/CD: GitHub Actions

# MODULE 7.2 : Platform Engineering (280h, 4000 XP)

## Vue d'ensemble

Ce module forme des Platform Engineers capables de construire des Internal Developer Platforms (IDP) qui améliorent la productivité de centaines de développeurs.

## Sous-module 7.2.1 : Platform Engineering Fundamentals (35h)

### 7.2.1.1 : What is Platform Engineering
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Platform engineering definition | Discipline of designing and building toolchains and workflows for self-service capabilities |
| b | Platform vs DevOps | Platform: product for developers, DevOps: culture and practices |
| c | Platform team | Team that builds and maintains internal platform |
| d | Platform customers | Internal developers |
| e | Platform product | Treat platform as product |
| f | Platform value | Developer productivity, consistency, compliance |
| g | Platform evolution | Ad-hoc → scripts → platform → self-service |
| h | Platform antipatterns | Ivory tower, mandatory adoption, no feedback |

### 7.2.1.2 : Internal Developer Platform (IDP)

|---|---------|------------------|

| c | IDP benefits | Faster onboarding, consistent environments, reduced cognitive load |
| d | IDP maturity model | Level 1 (basic) → Level 5 (optimized) |
| e | IDP scope | What to include, what to exclude |
| f | IDP adoption | Gradual rollout, champion users |

### Livrables Détaillés

| # | Livrable | Heures | Description |
|---|----------|--------|-------------|
| 1 | Backstage setup | 8h | Deploy and configure Backstage |
| 2 | Software catalog | 6h | Service registration and discovery |
| 3 | Service templates | 8h | Create 3+ service templates |
| 4 | TechDocs integration | 4h | Documentation in portal |
| 5 | Self-service databases | 8h | Database provisioning via Crossplane or operators |
| 6 | Pipeline templates | 6h | Reusable CI/CD templates |
| 7 | GitOps setup | 6h | ArgoCD configuration |
| 8 | Environment provisioning | 6h | Ephemeral environment creation |
| 9 | Secrets management | 4h | External Secrets integration |
| 10 | DORA dashboard | 4h | Metrics visualization |
| 11 | Integration tests | 2h | End-to-end testing |
| 12 | Documentation | 2h | Platform user guide |

### Technologies
- Portal: Backstage
- Infrastructure: Crossplane ou Terraform
- GitOps: ArgoCD
- CI/CD: GitHub Actions
- Secrets: External Secrets Operator + Vault
- Metrics: Prometheus + Grafana
- Database: PostgreSQL (catalog)

## PROJET 7.3 : Security Platform (64h)

### Architecture du Projet
```
Security Platform
├── Security Scanning Pipeline
│   ├── SAST integration
│   ├── SCA integration
```

## PROJET 7.5 : MLOps Platform (64h)

### Architecture du Projet
```
MLOps Platform
├── Data Pipeline
│   ├── Data ingestion
│   ├── Data validation (Great Expectations)
│   ├── Feature engineering
│   └── Feature store (Feast)
│
├── Experiment Tracking
│   ├── MLflow setup
│   ├── Experiment logging
│   ├── Artifact storage
│   └── Experiment comparison
│
├── Training Pipeline
│   ├── Kubeflow Pipelines
│   ├── Training components
│   ├── Hyperparameter tuning
│   └── Model validation
│
├── Model Registry
│   ├── Model versioning
│   ├── Model metadata
│   ├── Model stages
│   └── Approval workflow
│
├── Model Serving
│   ├── KServe deployment
│   ├── Canary deployment
│   ├── A/B testing
│   └── Auto-scaling
│
├── Monitoring
│   ├── Data drift detection
│   ├── Model performance
│   ├── Alerts
│   └── Dashboards
│
└── Governance
    ├── Model documentation
    ├── Lineage tracking
    ├── Access control
    └── Audit logging
```

### Livrables Détaillés

| # | Livrable | Heures | Description |
|---|----------|--------|-------------|
| 1 | Data pipeline | 8h | Ingestion, validation, transformation |
| 2 | Feature store | 6h | Feast deployment and features |
| 3 | MLflow setup | 4h | Experiment tracking |
| 4 | Training pipeline | 10h | Kubeflow pipeline |
| 5 | Model registry | 4h | Versioning and stages |
| 6 | Model serving | 8h | KServe with canary |
| 7 | A/B testing | 4h | Traffic splitting |
| 8 | Drift monitoring | 6h | Data and concept drift |
| 9 | Performance monitoring | 4h | Model metrics |
| 10 | Dashboards | 4h | Grafana dashboards |
| 11 | Documentation | 4h | Model cards, runbooks |
| 12 | Testing | 2h | Pipeline tests |

### Technologies
- Orchestration: Kubeflow Pipelines
- Feature Store: Feast
- Experiment Tracking: MLflow
- Serving: KServe
- Monitoring: Prometheus, Grafana, Evidently
- Storage: MinIO, PostgreSQL
- Kubernetes: Kind or GKE

## Module 8.1 : Final Capstone Project (140h, 2000 XP)

### Objectif
Construire un projet complet de A à Z démontrant toutes les compétences acquises.

### Options de Projet

#### Option A : Distributed Database
```
Distributed Database Engine
├── SQL Parser (Phase 6.1)
├── Query Optimizer (Phase 6.2)
├── Storage Engine (Phase 6.2)
├── Transaction Manager (Phase 5.2)
├── Raft Consensus (Phase 5.4)
├── Distributed Query Execution
└── Monitoring & Observability (Phase 7.1)
```

#### Option B : Cloud-Native Platform
```
Multi-tenant SaaS Platform
├── Microservices Architecture (Phase 5.6)
├── Event-Driven Design (Phase 5.6)
├── Kubernetes Deployment (Phase 7.4)
├── Multi-tenant Security (Phase 7.3)
├── Observability Stack (Phase 7.1)
└── CI/CD Pipeline (Phase 7.2)
```

#### Option C : ML Platform
```
End-to-End ML Platform
├── Data Pipeline (Phase 7.5)
├── Feature Store (Phase 7.5)
├── Training Pipeline (Phase 7.5)
├── Model Serving (Phase 7.5)
├── Monitoring (Phase 7.5)
└── Kubernetes Deployment (Phase 7.4)
```

#### Option D : Game Engine Component
```
Networked Game Server
├── Game Engine Basics (Phase 4)
├── Physics Engine (Phase 4)
├── Networking Layer (Phase 5.1)
├── Real-time Sync (Phase 5.4)
├── Matchmaking Service (Phase 5.6)
└── Deployment (Phase 7.4)
```

## Conclusion

Le curriculum POKÉOS révisé offre maintenant :

### ✅ Points Forts
1. **Exhaustivité** : Couvre tous les domaines de l'informatique moderne
2. **Cohérence** : Timeline sans conflits, progression logique
3. **Profondeur** : ~5000 sous-sous-modules détaillés
4. **Pratique** : 500+ exercices LeetCode, 40+ projets majeurs
5. **Industrie** : Aligné avec les attentes professionnelles actuelles
6. **Originalité** : Zéro duplication entre les phases

### 📊 Statistiques Finales
- **Durée** : ~3 ans (154 semaines)
- **Heures** : 10500h (~70h/semaine full-time ou ~35h/semaine part-time sur 6 ans)
- **XP** : 150000 points
- **Modules** : 38 modules complets
- **Projets** : 40+ projets substantiels

### 🎯 Résultat Attendu
À la fin du curriculum, l'étudiant sera un **ingénieur logiciel complet** capable de :
- Concevoir et implémenter des systèmes distribués à grande échelle
- Opérer des infrastructures cloud de production
- Développer des applications full-stack modernes
- Créer des outils et langages de programmation
- Implémenter des systèmes ML en production
- Mener des équipes techniques

2. Des détails supplémentaires sur une phase particulière ?
3. Un plan d'étude personnalisé basé sur des objectifs spécifiques ?

# PHASES 8 & 9 RESTRUCTURÉES : Specialization & Capstone

# MODULE 8.0 : Tronc Commun Obligatoire (560h, 8000 XP)

## Module 8.0.1 : Advanced System Design (280h, 4000 XP)

### Vue d'Ensemble

Ce module prépare aux entretiens system design de niveau Staff/Principal et développe une expertise en architecture de systèmes à grande échelle.

### Références
| Source | Contenu |
|--------|---------|
| Designing Data-Intensive Applications | Martin Kleppmann |
| System Design Interview Vol 1 & 2 | Alex Xu |
| MIT 6.824 | Distributed Systems |
| Stanford CS245 | Database Systems Principles |

---

### Sous-module 8.0.1.1 : System Design Fundamentals (35h)

#### 8.0.1.1.1 : Requirements Analysis
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Functional requirements | Core features, user stories, use cases |
| b | Non-functional requirements | Scalability, availability, latency, consistency |
| c | Capacity estimation | Users, QPS, storage, bandwidth |
| d | Back-of-envelope calculations | Order of magnitude estimates |
| e | Traffic patterns | Read/write ratio, peak vs average |
| f | Data characteristics | Size, growth rate, access patterns |
| g | Constraints identification | Budget, timeline, team size |
| h | Scope definition | MVP vs full solution |

#### 8.0.1.1.2 : Scalability Patterns
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Vertical scaling | Scale up, hardware limits |
| b | Horizontal scaling | Scale out, stateless design |
| c | Load balancing | Round robin, least connections, consistent hashing |
| d | Database scaling | Read replicas, sharding, partitioning |
| e | Caching strategies | Cache-aside, write-through, write-back |
| f | CDN | Static content, edge computing |
| g | Async processing | Message queues, event-driven |
| h | Microservices | Service decomposition |

#### 8.0.1.1.3 : Availability & Reliability
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Availability math | Nines, uptime calculation |
| b | Redundancy | Active-passive, active-active |
| c | Failover | Automatic, manual, DNS failover |
| d | Replication | Synchronous, asynchronous |
| e | Disaster recovery | RTO, RPO, backup strategies |
| f | Health checks | Liveness, readiness |
| g | Circuit breakers | Fail fast, graceful degradation |
| h | Chaos engineering | Fault injection, game days |

#### 8.0.1.1.4 : Consistency Models
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Strong consistency | Linearizability |
| b | Eventual consistency | BASE |
| c | Causal consistency | Happens-before |
| d | Read-your-writes | Session consistency |
| e | CAP theorem | Trade-offs |
| f | PACELC | Extended CAP |
| g | Consensus protocols | Paxos, Raft |
| h | Conflict resolution | LWW, vector clocks, CRDTs |

#### 8.0.1.1.5 : Data Storage Selection
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Relational databases | ACID, joins, transactions |
| b | Document stores | Schema flexibility, denormalization |
| c | Key-value stores | High throughput, simple access |
| d | Wide-column stores | Time series, analytics |
| e | Graph databases | Relationships, traversals |
| f | Search engines | Full-text, relevance |
| g | Time series databases | Metrics, IoT |
| h | Blob storage | Files, media |

---

### Sous-module 8.0.1.2 : Classic System Design Problems (70h)

#### 8.0.1.2.1 : URL Shortener (TinyURL)
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Requirements | Shorten URL, redirect, analytics |
| b | ID generation | Counter, hash, base62 encoding |
| c | Database choice | Key-value optimal |
| d | Read-heavy optimization | Caching, CDN |
| e | Collision handling | Check and retry |
| f | Custom aliases | User-defined short URLs |
| g | Expiration | TTL, cleanup |
| h | Analytics | Click tracking, geo, referrer |
| i | Rate limiting | Abuse prevention |
| j | High availability | Replication, multi-region |

#### 8.0.1.2.2 : Pastebin
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Requirements | Store text, share, expire |
| b | Storage | Blob storage for content |
| c | Metadata | Database for metadata |
| d | Size limits | Quotas, compression |
| e | Syntax highlighting | Client-side processing |
| f | Privacy | Public, unlisted, private |
| g | Expiration | TTL options |
| h | API design | REST endpoints |

#### 8.0.1.2.3 : Rate Limiter
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Algorithms | Token bucket, leaky bucket, fixed window, sliding window |
| b | Token bucket | Tokens, refill rate, burst |
| c | Leaky bucket | Queue, constant rate |
| d | Fixed window | Time windows, counters |
| e | Sliding window log | Timestamp tracking |
| f | Sliding window counter | Hybrid approach |
| g | Distributed rate limiting | Redis, consensus |
| h | Rate limit headers | X-RateLimit-* |
| i | Graceful handling | 429 responses, retry-after |
| j | Multi-tier limits | User, IP, API key |

#### 8.0.1.2.4 : Consistent Hashing
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Problem | Rehashing on node changes |
| b | Hash ring | Circular space |
| c | Virtual nodes | Even distribution |
| d | Node addition | Minimal redistribution |
| e | Node removal | Automatic rebalancing |
| f | Replication | N nodes clockwise |
| g | Implementation | TreeMap, sorted array |
| h | Use cases | Distributed caches, databases |

#### 8.0.1.2.5 : Key-Value Store
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Single server | Hash table, persistence |
| b | Distributed | Partitioning, replication |
| c | Partitioning | Consistent hashing |
| d | Replication | Quorum, read/write |
| e | Consistency | Tunable consistency |
| f | Failure detection | Gossip protocol |
| g | Handling failures | Hinted handoff, anti-entropy |
| h | Merkle trees | Synchronization |
| i | Write path | Commit log, memtable, SSTable |
| j | Read path | Memtable, bloom filter, SSTable |

#### 8.0.1.2.6 : Unique ID Generator
| # | Concept | Contenu détaillé |
|---|---------|------------------|
| a | Requirements | Unique, sortable, distributed |
| b | UUID | Pros and cons |
| c | Database auto-increment | Single point of failure |
| d | Ticket server | Centralized, batching |
| e | Twitter Snowflake | Timestamp + worker + sequence |
| f | Instagram ID | Similar to Snowflake |
| g | ULID | Lexicographically sortable |
| h | Clock synchronization | NTP, logical clocks |

# TRACK A : Mobile Engineering (560h, 8000 XP)

## Vue d'Ensemble

Ce track forme des Mobile Engineers capables de développer des applications natives et cross-platform de qualité production.

### Timeline
- **Track Principal** : 4 modules × 140h = 560h
- **Track Secondaire** : 2 modules × 140h = 280h

### Références
| Source | Contenu |
|--------|---------|
| Stanford CS193P | iOS Development (SwiftUI) |
| Google Android Developers | Android Development |
| React Native Documentation | Cross-platform |
| Meta Engineering Blog | Mobile at scale |

---

### Sous-module A.1.4 : Project - Social Media App (35h)

#### Architecture
```
Social Media App (React Native)
├── Authentication
│   ├── Email/password
│   ├── Social login (Google, Apple)
│   ├── Biometric login
│   └── Session management
│
├── Feed
│   ├── Infinite scroll
│   ├── Pull to refresh
│   ├── Image/video posts
│   ├── Like, comment, share
│   └── Real-time updates
│
├── Profile
│   ├── User profile
│   ├── Edit profile
│   ├── Profile picture upload
│   ├── Follow/followers
│   └── Settings
│
├── Messaging
│   ├── Real-time chat
│   ├── Typing indicators
│   ├── Read receipts
│   └── Media sharing
│
├── Camera
│   ├── Photo capture
│   ├── Video recording
│   ├── Filters (Skia)
│   └── Story creation
│
├── Notifications
│   ├── Push notifications
│   ├── In-app notifications
│   └── Notification preferences
│
└── Offline
    ├── Offline feed viewing
    ├── Queue actions
    └── Sync on reconnect
```

#### Livrables

| # | Livrable | Heures | Description |
|---|----------|--------|-------------|
| 1 | Project setup | 2h | Expo, TypeScript, navigation |
| 2 | Authentication | 4h | Auth flow with Firebase |
| 3 | Feed implementation | 6h | FlatList, infinite scroll |
| 4 | Post creation | 4h | Camera, media picker |
| 5 | Animations | 4h | Reanimated, gestures |
| 6 | Real-time features | 4h | WebSocket, Firebase |
| 7 | Profile & settings | 4h | User management |
| 8 | Messaging | 4h | Chat implementation |
| 9 | Testing | 3h | Unit, integration tests |
| 10 | CI/CD | 2h | EAS Build, distribution |
| 11 | Performance | 2h | Optimization, profiling |

# RÉCAPITULATIF FINAL PHASES 8 & 9

## Statistiques Globales

| Phase | Semaines | Heures | XP | Modules |
|-------|----------|--------|-----|---------|
| Phase 8 | 20 | 1400h | 20000 | Tronc (560h) + Track (560h) + Secondaire (280h) |
| Phase 9 | 16 | 1120h | 16000 | Theory + Research + Capstone + Career |
| **TOTAL** | **36** | **2520h** | **36000** | |

## Track Récapitulatif

| Track | Heures | Modules | Focus |
|-------|--------|---------|-------|
| A: Mobile | 560h | RN, Android, iOS, DevOps | Mobile Engineering |
| B: Systems | 560h | Kernel, Drivers, RTOS, Safety | Systems Engineering |
| C: AI/ML | 560h | DL, LLMs, CV, Production | ML Engineering |
| D: FinTech | 560h | Trading, Risk, Payments, DeFi | Financial Engineering |
| E: Game | 560h | Engine, Graphics, Systems, Network | Game Engineering |

## Compétences Finales par Track

| Track | Rôles Préparés |
|-------|----------------|
| A | Mobile Engineer, iOS/Android Developer |
| B | Systems Engineer, Embedded Developer, Kernel Developer |
| C | ML Engineer, AI Engineer, Research Scientist |
| D | Quant Developer, FinTech Engineer, Blockchain Developer |
| E | Game Engineer, Graphics Programmer, Engine Developer |

## Timeline Complète POKÉOS

```
Phase 0: Fundamentals           Weeks   1-12   ( 12 sem,   840h,  12000 XP)
Phase 1: Algorithms & DS        Weeks  13-34   ( 22 sem,  1540h,  22000 XP)
Phase 2: Operating Systems      Weeks  35-58   ( 24 sem,  1680h,  24000 XP)
Phase 5: Backend & Distributed  Weeks  59-82   ( 24 sem,  1680h,  24000 XP)
Phase 4: Graphics & Games       Weeks  83-98   ( 16 sem,  1120h,  16000 XP)
Phase 6: Advanced Topics        Weeks  99-122  ( 24 sem,  1680h,  24000 XP)
Phase 7: Advanced Operations    Weeks 123-142  ( 20 sem,  1400h,  20000 XP)
Phase 8: Specialization         Weeks 143-162  ( 20 sem,  1400h,  20000 XP)
Phase 9: Theory & Capstone      Weeks 163-178  ( 16 sem,  1120h,  16000 XP)

TOTAL: 178 semaines (~3.4 ans), 12460h, 178000 XP
```

---

Ce curriculum complet forme un **ingénieur logiciel de classe mondiale** capable de :

1. **Maîtriser les fondamentaux** (Phases 0-2)
2. **Construire des systèmes distribués** (Phases 5-6)
3. **Opérer à grande échelle** (Phase 7)
4. **Se spécialiser profondément** (Phase 8)
5. **Contribuer à la recherche** (Phase 9)
6. **Lancer une carrière réussie** (Phase 9)
